data.title: Constructing a dream 26-man roster for the last 26 years for every team in Major League Baseball
data.meta_description: In which we dig up a years-old thought exercise, modernize it slightly, and do it thirty times
data.text:
Sometimes, you just have to do one for yourself.

One of the most superfluous posts I’ve ever written is also one of my favorites–this little one from Viva El Birdos on February 2018, based on a thought exercise devised by Russell Carleton in which you must construct a full roster for your favorite team based on the prevoius 25 seasons (at the time, MLB rosters had 25 players) in which you could pick a player out of each of the last 25 seasons but you could not repeat seasons nor players. It was a fun little thing in which people got mad at me for not including 2003 Edgar Rentería even though this would have meant removing the greatest Albert Pujols season of them all from the team.

Anyway, it’s a few years later and the roster is now 26 players large, so I decided to create it for the Cardinals again. Obviously, there is considerable overlap, but it is not absolute. But I didn’t just stop there. I created a 26-man roster for twenty-eight MLB teams, and a 24-man roster for the Arizona Diamondbacks and Tampa Bay Rays (the two teams which have only played for 24 seasons).

I listed my teams below for each franchise, but here are a few caveats.

The 2020 season is a complicated one, but by and large, I extrapolated the 60-game season to a 162-game pace. Yes, this creates some small sample size theater, but in the end I’m going to wind up representing 2020 by necessity on every team anyway, so I’d rather do this than just put the final relief pitcher on every roster as a 2020 guy in order to preserve some kind of Wins Above Replacement equilibrium.

I gave priority to starting lineups and starting rotations. My whole objective is construct an actual team and these guys have more of an impact than bench players or deep bullpen guys. I gave, say, closers priority over bench bats, but was more receptive to bench bats over fifth or sixth guys out of bullpens. There are exceptions–elite relief pitchers who are just that much better than other candidates, for instance–but this is my general philosophy.

Each 26-man roster has 14 position players–this is not necessarily the way most rosters are constructed in 2021, but it is the way most rosters would likely have been constructed throughout the bulk of the 1996-2021 period covered in this exercise. For AL teams, I worked in a designated hitter, though it was not always a real-life committed DH, and for both leagues, I tried to include enough positional versatility that the 14 players included at least two players who could plausibly handle each position. Each 24-man roster has 13 position players.

The Houston Astros and Milwaukee Brewers don’t get a DH, based on spending a majority of the time frame in the National League.

Each team has six starters–this was my compromise to avoid filling out an entire pitching staff of starting pitchers under the probably-true logic that most of a team’s sixth through twelfth best starting pitchers (or eleventh, for the Diamondbacks and Rays) would be worthy of bullpen roles. In most cases, though, the sixth starter was whatever season I had left over. That said, it’s usually a pretty good pitcher, anyway.

Every team includes at least one left-handed relief pitcher. And also at least one right-handed relief pitcher, though that was never a significant hurdle to clear.

Here we go. Please feel free to create your own team(s) and yell at me in the comments or on Twitter about them.

C: 2012 Yadier Molina

1B: 1998 Mark McGwire

2B: 2013 Matt Carpenter
